# Towards an Evolutionary Platonism {#towards-an-evolutionary-platonism .post-title .published .title-X77sOw dir="auto"}

### Reflections after participating in today\'s Platonic Space Symposium Discussion {#reflections-after-participating-in-todays-platonic-space-symposium-discussion .subtitle .subtitle-HEEcLo dir="auto"}

::: {.pencraft .pc-display-flex .pc-flexDirection-column .pc-paddingBottom-16 .pc-reset aria-label="Post UFI" role="region"}
::: {.pencraft .pc-display-flex .pc-flexDirection-column .pc-paddingTop-16 .pc-paddingBottom-16 .pc-reset}
::: {.pencraft .pc-display-flex .pc-gap-12 .pc-alignItems-center .pc-reset .byline-wrapper}
::: {.pencraft .pc-display-flex .pc-reset}
::: {.pencraft .pc-display-flex .pc-flexDirection-row .pc-gap-8 .pc-alignItems-center .pc-justifyContent-flex-start .pc-reset}
::: {.pencraft .pc-display-flex .pc-flexDirection-row .pc-alignItems-center .pc-justifyContent-flex-start .pc-reset .ltr-qDBmby style="--scale:36px;--offset:9px;--border-width:4.5px;"}
[](https://substack.com/@footnotes2plato){.pencraft .pc-display-contents .pc-reset aria-label="View Matthew David Segall's profile"}

::: {.pencraft .pc-display-flex .pc-width-36 .pc-height-36 .pc-justifyContent-center .pc-alignItems-center .pc-position-relative .pc-reset .bg-secondary-UUD3_J .flex-auto-j3S2WA .animate-XFJxE4 .outline-detail-vcQLyr .pc-borderRadius-full .overflow-hidden-WdpwT6 .sizing-border-box-DggLA4 .pressable-sm-YIJFKJ .showFocus-sk_vEm .container-TAtrWj .interactive-UkK0V6 .avatar-u8q6xB .last-JfNEJ_ style="--scale:36px;" tabindex="0"}
::: {.pencraft .pc-display-flex .pc-width-36 .pc-height-36 .pc-justifyContent-center .pc-alignItems-center .pc-position-relative .pc-reset .bg-secondary-UUD3_J .flex-auto-j3S2WA .outline-detail-vcQLyr .pc-borderRadius-full .overflow-hidden-WdpwT6 .sizing-border-box-DggLA4 .container-TAtrWj style="--scale:36px;" title="Matthew David Segall"}
![Matthew David Segall\'s avatar](https://substackcdn.com/image/fetch/$s_!Pn1B!,w_36,h_36,c_fill,f_auto,q_auto:good,fl_progressive:steep/https%3A%2F%2Fsubstack-post-media.s3.amazonaws.com%2Fpublic%2Fimages%2F934a1731-e35b-4dca-ab91-ae7c8e42cb9f_1024x1024.png){.img-OACg1c .object-fit-cover-u4ReeV .pencraft .pc-reset sizes="36px" srcset="https://substackcdn.com/image/fetch/$s_!Pn1B!,w_36,h_36,c_fill,f_auto,q_auto:good,fl_progressive:steep/https%3A%2F%2Fsubstack-post-media.s3.amazonaws.com%2Fpublic%2Fimages%2F934a1731-e35b-4dca-ab91-ae7c8e42cb9f_1024x1024.png 36w, https://substackcdn.com/image/fetch/$s_!Pn1B!,w_72,h_72,c_fill,f_auto,q_auto:good,fl_progressive:steep/https%3A%2F%2Fsubstack-post-media.s3.amazonaws.com%2Fpublic%2Fimages%2F934a1731-e35b-4dca-ab91-ae7c8e42cb9f_1024x1024.png 72w, https://substackcdn.com/image/fetch/$s_!Pn1B!,w_108,h_108,c_fill,f_auto,q_auto:good,fl_progressive:steep/https%3A%2F%2Fsubstack-post-media.s3.amazonaws.com%2Fpublic%2Fimages%2F934a1731-e35b-4dca-ab91-ae7c8e42cb9f_1024x1024.png 108w" width="36" height="36" draggable="false"}

::: {.body .markup dir="auto"}
I mentioned yesterday in the post below that I'd soon be participating in the next discussion group following the [Platonic Space Symposium](https://thoughtforms.life/symposium-on-the-platonic-space/){rel=""}.

::: {.digestPostEmbed-flwiST component-name="DigestPostEmbed"}
[](https://footnotes2plato.substack.com/p/platonism-after-darwin-mathematical){rel="noopener" target="_blank"}

::: {.pencraft .pc-display-flex .pc-gap-16 .pc-reset}
::: {.pencraft .pc-reset style="width:70px;height:70px;"}
![Platonism After Darwin: Mathematical Potentiality and the Creative Advance](https://substackcdn.com/image/fetch/$s_!uDtg!,w_140,h_140,c_fill,f_auto,q_auto:good,fl_progressive:steep,g_auto/https%3A%2F%2Fsubstack-video.s3.amazonaws.com%2Fvideo_upload%2Fpost%2F186043010%2Fee838d10-b5b3-4737-8c89-28b28c8c07dd%2Ftranscoded-1769573942.png){.img-OACg1c .smSquare-NGbPBa .pencraft .pc-reset sizes="100vw" width="140" height="140"}
:::

::: {.pencraft .pc-display-flex .pc-flexDirection-column .pc-reset}
#### Platonism After Darwin: Mathematical Potentiality and the Creative Advance {#platonism-after-darwin-mathematical-potentiality-and-the-creative-advance .pencraft .pc-reset .color-pub-primary-text-NyXPlw .line-height-24-jnGwiv .font-display-nhmvtD .size-20-P_cSRT .weight-bold-DmI9lw .reset-IxiVJZ}

::: {.pencraft .pc-display-flex .pc-gap-4 .pc-alignItems-center .pc-reset}
::: {.pencraft .pc-reset .color-pub-secondary-text-hGQ02T .line-height-20-t4M0El .font-meta-MWBumP .size-11-NuY2Zx .weight-medium-fw81nC .transform-uppercase-yKDgcq .reset-IxiVJZ .meta-EgzBVA}
[Matthew David Segall](https://substack.com/profile/139089458-matthew-david-segall){.inheritColor-WetTGJ}
:::

::: {.pencraft .pc-reset .color-pub-secondary-text-hGQ02T .reset-IxiVJZ}

Jan 28

::: {.pencraft .pc-display-flex .pc-gap-16 .pc-paddingTop-0 .pc-paddingBottom-0 .pc-alignItems-center .pc-reset}
[](https://footnotes2plato.substack.com/p/platonism-after-darwin-mathematical){.pencraft .pc-reset .align-center-y7ZD4w .line-height-20-t4M0El .font-text-qe4AeH .size-13-hZTUKr .weight-medium-fw81nC .reset-IxiVJZ}

That next discussion was earlier today. You can watch it below:

::: {#youtube2-r7eMr8za1DY .youtube-wrap attrs="{\"videoId\":\"r7eMr8za1DY\",\"startTime\":null,\"endTime\":null}" component-name="Youtube2ToDOM"}
::: youtube-inner
::: iframe
::: {#player}
:::

::: player-unavailable
# An error occurred. {#an-error-occurred. .message}

::: submessage
Unable to execute JavaScript.
:::
:::
:::
:::
:::

I enjoyed it immensely, and wrote up some preliminary reflections below based on my comments.

[[Michael Levin](https://open.substack.com/users/48096250-michael-levin?utm_source=mentions){.mention-pnpTE1 target="_blank" rel="noopener" attrs="{\"name\":\"Michael Levin\",\"id\":48096250,\"type\":\"user\",\"url\":null,\"photo_url\":\"https://substack-post-media.s3.amazonaws.com/public/images/b36aef42-623c-491d-8888-4890893df5df_618x618.png\",\"uuid\":\"604e9d8a-9d13-4be5-b565-b4e08c5c3ebe\"}" component-name="MentionUser"}]{state="closed"} and Hananel Hazan will be trying to create a typology of the variety of views contributed to the Symposium. In our discussion, [[Timothy Jackson](https://open.substack.com/users/28229704-timothy-jackson?utm_source=mentions){.mention-pnpTE1 target="_blank" rel="noopener" attrs="{\"name\":\"Timothy Jackson\",\"id\":28229704,\"type\":\"user\",\"url\":null,\"photo_url\":\"https://substackcdn.com/image/fetch/f_auto,q_auto:good,fl_progressive:steep/https%3A%2F%2Fbucketeer-e05bbc84-baa3-437e-9518-adb32be77984.s3.amazonaws.com%2Fpublic%2Fimages%2F2fae2d40-0c23-4f4c-8684-90ff26500605_814x1087.png\",\"uuid\":\"3a6996bd-ea2b-47be-859d-7dd8bc94a8ca\"}" component-name="MentionUser"}]{state="closed"} preliminarily proposed a fourfold typology of 1) mechanical philosophy, 2) Platonism, 3) neo-Darwinism, and 4) speculative Darwinism (generalizing variation-and-selection beyond biology). Each offers a somewhat different answer to the question of whether "forms" are discovered or invented.

I suggested we might even simplify Tim's fourfold scheme down to Platonism vs Darwinism. The mechanical philosophy, rooted in the determinism of Newtonian mathematical laws of physics, and neo-Darwinism, with its story about genetic molecules encoding phenotype determining "information," both strike me as degraded or implicit Platonisms, because they smuggle in something very much like pre-given forms. Although he did not himself see how evolution might apply beyond the biosphere to the cosmos at large (he famously references "the fixed law of gravity" in the final pages of *Origin*), Darwin is the real alternative to Plato. He gave pride of place to variation, allowing the variety of special forms to be accounted for as historically accumulated through variation and selection.

> **"There is grandeur in this view of life, with its several powers, having been originally breathed into a few forms or into one; and that, whilst this planet has gone cycling on according to the fixed law of gravity, from so simple a beginning endless forms most beautiful and most wonderful have been, and are being, evolved."**

I also tried to loosen the reflexive allergy to "Platonism" among many empirical scientists by reminding that Plato's dialogues don't hand down a single doctrine. The sharpest criticisms of Plato's theory of forms are elaborated in Plato's dialogues.

For my part, I refuse what I take to be a forced choice between "variation first" and "invariance first." If variation is to yield anything significant, it needs seeds of invariance. Some forms may be genuinely or at the very least practically invariant (from our perspective as observers), enabling a selection process through which other more contingent forms can emerge historically. I want it both ways!: an account of endless emergent forms most beautiful (in Whitehead's terms, novel societies sheltering actual occasions of experience capable of entertaining novel complex propositions) that doesn't deny but may even metaphysically require the reality of invariances as a source of relevant selection. You could call my position **Evolutionary Platonism**.[[1](https://footnotes2plato.substack.com/p/towards-an-evolutionary-platonism?r=i2ht&utm_medium=ios&shareImageVariant=overlay&triedRedirect=true#footnote-1-186162113){#footnote-anchor-1-186162113 .footnote-anchor component-name="FootnoteAnchorToDOM" target="_self" rel=""}]{state="closed"}

::: captioned-image-container
<figure>
<a href="https://substackcdn.com/image/fetch/$s_!JLA-!,f_auto,q_auto:good,fl_progressive:steep/https%3A%2F%2Fsubstack-post-media.s3.amazonaws.com%2Fpublic%2Fimages%2Face6b60e-5549-4d5a-a3a3-b47f24395f8a_1536x1024.png" class="image-link image2 is-viewable-img can-restack" target="_blank" data-component-name="Image2ToDOM" rel=""></a>
<div class="image2-inset can-restack">
<img class="sizing-normal" data-attrs="{&quot;src&quot;:&quot;https://substack-post-media.s3.amazonaws.com/public/images/ace6b60e-5549-4d5a-a3a3-b47f24395f8a_1536x1024.png&quot;,&quot;srcNoWatermark&quot;:null,&quot;fullscreen&quot;:null,&quot;imageSize&quot;:null,&quot;height&quot;:971,&quot;width&quot;:1456,&quot;resizeWidth&quot;:null,&quot;bytes&quot;:2332781,&quot;alt&quot;:null,&quot;title&quot;:null,&quot;type&quot;:&quot;image/png&quot;,&quot;href&quot;:null,&quot;belowTheFold&quot;:true,&quot;topImage&quot;:false,&quot;internalRedirect&quot;:&quot;https://footnotes2plato.substack.com/i/186162113?img=https%3A%2F%2Fsubstack-post-media.s3.amazonaws.com%2Fpublic%2Fimages%2Face6b60e-5549-4d5a-a3a3-b47f24395f8a_1536x1024.png&quot;,&quot;isProcessing&quot;:false,&quot;align&quot;:null,&quot;offset&quot;:false}" srcset="https://substackcdn.com/image/fetch/$s_!JLA-!,w_424,c_limit,f_auto,q_auto:good,fl_progressive:steep/https%3A%2F%2Fsubstack-post-media.s3.amazonaws.com%2Fpublic%2Fimages%2Face6b60e-5549-4d5a-a3a3-b47f24395f8a_1536x1024.png 848w, https://substackcdn.com/image/fetch/$s_!JLA-!,w_1272,c_limit,f_auto,q_auto:good,fl_progressive:steep/https%3A%2F%2Fsubstack-post-media.s3.amazonaws.com%2Fpublic%2Fimages%2Face6b60e-5549-4d5a-a3a3-b47f24395f8a_1536x1024.png 1272w, https://substackcdn.com/image/fetch/$s_!JLA-!,w_1456,c_limit,f_auto,q_auto:good,fl_progressive:steep/https%3A%2F%2Fsubstack-post-media.s3.amazonaws.com%2Fpublic%2Fimages%2Face6b60e-5549-4d5a-a3a3-b47f24395f8a_1536x1024.png <div class="image-link-expand">
<div class="pencraft pc-display-flex pc-gap-8 pc-reset">
<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," />

</div>
</div>
</figure>
:::

My admission above that form may be invariant only relative to our perspective as observers speaks to [David Resnik](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/David_Resnik){rel=""}'s apropos mention of Kant during our discussion. Kant's revolutionary transcendental philosophy argues that whatever reality may be "in itself," any reality that can appear for us must already be structured by conditions of possible experience: forms of intuition (space and time) and categories (causality, substance, etc.). These are not extra entities in a Platonic heaven, but the enabling invariances of intelligibility, what makes a world count as a world for finite knowers like us. Kant's *a prioris* are, at minimum, practically invariant from the standpoint of observers embedded in a cosmos canalized by ancient regularities. We never meet "pure variation" but only variation against a background of habits, constraints, and repeatable relations that make discrimination, memory, inference, and valuation, etc., possible at all.

Schelling's *Naturphilosophie* already does what would be required decades later by Darwin: he evolutionizes Kant. The transcendental structure of human Reason cannot just be inserted into the mind of man from nowhere. Schelling traces its genesis in a dynamic series of stages in nature itself. The transcendental reflexivity of human consciousness becomes a living achievement of nature's self-organizing history, with mind as a higher potency of nature reflecting on its own creative intelligibility, rather than a disembodied observer imposing a fixed set of rules upon a passive material world.

Tim and I had been talking offline before this discussion about the limits of natural language and the need for formalization. As the discussion wrapped up, I emphasized that Plato doesn't simply translate myth into logic. His dialogues play dialectic and myth off each other: dialectic pushes the intellect to its limits in aporia, then myth renders imaginatively what reason cannot grasp abstractly. However far science and computation may take us, we still need stories about what the formalisms mean for our human self-understanding.

As we wrapped up, the discussion shifted to the different sorts of explanations that science might seek of a given or of various multi-level phenomena. This reminded me of Aristotle's four *aitia*, a term often translated as "cause" but which means something more like "reasons" or "modes of explanation." Material, efficient, formal, and final modes of explanation were enumerated by Aristotle as being required for a comprehensive understanding of something. There's no question that Aristotle was wrong about a lot of things (eg, uniform acceleration, women as deformed men, natural slaves, etc.). But it seems to me that much of contemporary complex systems science is rediscovering emergent evolutionary versions of what he called *entelechy*. There are no static, pre-given, externally imposed forms in Aristotle's metaphysics: entelechy refers to the condition of something that is not merely potential but actively realizing its form. Nowadays, systems scientists might refer to dynamic attractors instead.

My final contribution was to differentiate metaphysics from the special sciences (without thereby making them unaccountable to one another). The sciences offer domain specific *explanations* keyed to precisely isolated problems, while metaphysics seeks *descriptive* *generalization* across such domains, serving as the "critic of abstraction" (Whitehead) by reminding the special sciences to avoid the temptation to assert one cause to rule them all.

::: {.footnote component-name="FootnoteToDOM"}
[1](https://footnotes2plato.substack.com/p/towards-an-evolutionary-platonism?r=i2ht&utm_medium=ios&shareImageVariant=overlay&triedRedirect=true#footnote-anchor-1-186162113){#footnote-1-186162113 .footnote-number contenteditable="false" target="_self" rel=""}

::: footnote-content
In *Process and Reality* (p. 91-4), Whitehead contrasts Newton's *Scholium* with Plato's *Timaeus* to argue that, judged in light of contemporary evolutionary cosmology, Plato is actually the more modern of the two. Whitehead treats our current cosmic epoch as a vast society of nested societies (electronic, protonic, etc.) whose apparent "laws" are in fact statistical regularities emergent from historically achieved patterns of social order and reproduction, shot through with arbitrariness and failure, and always unstable enough at the edges to be on the verge of realizing new orders. Newton's *Scholium*, by contrast, presupposes fully formed space, time, matter, and forces, all ready-made for an initial divine shove, with no hint of *natura naturans*, no evolution of matter, and no sense of the limited applicability of its effective abstractions. Plato's *Timaeus*, though scientifically superseded in its details, is philosophically deeper because it links the behaviour of things to their formal natures, treats sharply distinguished kinds as arising from underlying molecular and mathematical structures, and imagines the current world-order as emerging from an antecedent chaos through the establishment of new dominant societies of forms. For Whitehead, this Platonic picture of cosmogenesis as the incoming of a certain type of order that inaugurates a cosmic epoch is far closer to an evolutionary universe of changing laws, quantum discontinuities, and emergent species than Newton's static, divinely designed system.
:::
:::
:::
:::

::: visibility-check
:::

[[2d]{.pencraft .pc-reset .color-secondary-ls1g8s .line-height-20-t4M0El .font-text-qe4AeH .size-13-hZTUKr .weight-regular-mUq6Gb .reset-IxiVJZ}](https://footnotes2plato.substack.com/p/towards-an-evolutionary-platonism/comment/207104819 "Jan 29, 2026, 8:07 PM"){.pencraft .pc-reset .color-secondary-ls1g8s .decoration-hover-underline-ClDVRM .reset-IxiVJZ rel="nofollow" native=""}

Liked by Matthew David Segall
:::
:::

::: {.pencraft .pc-display-flex .pc-flexDirection-column .pc-reset .flex-grow-rzmknG}
:::

::: {.pencraft .pc-display-flex .pc-reset .triggerContainer-eX588u}
![](data:image/svg+xml;base64,){.lucide .lucide-ellipsis}
:::
:::

::: {.comment-body .expanded}
Matt, helpful summary as always. I am continually amazed at how well Whitehead as you interpret him still benignly corrects and helps others stay out of the seduction of misplaced concreteness in favor of one abstract cause to deductively rule them all. Scientifically and Metaphysically, including variance as a priori and so abstractly invariant, or any move to reduce ANW to a fundamental \"facticity.\" It also amazes me how well Whitehead could live within the intensity of contrasts without capitulating to reductive abstract certitudes to relieve the tension. Hope I am making sense. I have learned a lot following your friendly and open dialectics with others. I also appreciate your ability here to include Aristotle\'s 4 reasons (not reifying them as fixed \"causes\"), and the analogy of entelechy with \"dynamic attractors.\" Thanks as usual. A question\... I signed up for the Rosa reading group. Do you and Tripp prefer we have the entire book read before our first meeting? - John B.
:::

::: {.pencraft .pc-display-flex .pc-gap-16 .pc-paddingTop-8 .pc-justifyContent-flex-start .pc-alignItems-center .pc-reset .comment-actions .withShareButton-hQzuEn}

Liked by Matthew David Segall
:::
:::

::: {.pencraft .pc-display-flex .pc-flexDirection-column .pc-reset .flex-grow-rzmknG}

::: {.pencraft .pc-display-flex .pc-reset .triggerContainer-eX588u}
![](data:image/svg+xml;base64,){.lucide .lucide-ellipsis}
:::
:::

::: {.comment-body .expanded}
I do not believe that, correctly understood, Platonic forms are opposed to Darwinian evolution. How forms come to be in the world, through what sort of processes, is distinct from the form as an eternal possibility, the form in its intelligible structure, which is the form proper.
:::

::: {.pencraft .pc-display-flex .pc-gap-16 .pc-paddingTop-8 .pc-justifyContent-flex-start .pc-alignItems-center .pc-reset .comment-actions .withShareButton-hQzuEn}
